title: AP Itemisation Context
body:
Hey everyone, Trading Stance aka PhRoXzOn aka Fizz Enthusiast here.
 
We’re in the process of spinning up work on AP Itemisation and I wanted to drop some quick context as we move forward with the project. First off, this is part of the game I’m really passionate about, and as a mage/AP assassin player for ~3 seasons now, I definitely resonate with various aspects of the community sentiment on both the boons and flaws of current AP itemisation. Also the lack of itemisation choices are obviously holding me back from Master tier.

This is something we've been talking about for a long time and we felt that now was a good time. 
 
I’m not going to go into detail on exact tactics and problems here (that will be once things are more fleshed out), but will talk a bit about goals and some of the things to think about when tackling opportunities here.
 
Primary Goal
·         Create contextual choices amongst items (especially amongst first items), we want items to be the correct purchase in some circumstances, and not in others. 
 
Notes
·         This will not be a complete overhaul of the AP item system as we want to actually get this out the door in a reasonable time frame.
·         There are a myriad of things to think about in this space so bear with us – it will be a time consuming project along with the other things I’m working on!
 
I’m expecting to post another update to this when the time comes, so stay tuned. Thanks for being patient.

replies.body:
Can we expect a more... structured framework? With mid-size components that solve specific problems early on during the laning, and multiple situational upgrades that you can choose between later on? Like the family of Zeal items for ADC, or the various defensive items for ADC all built out of Vamp Scepter? Or like Hexdrinker and Bramblevest for Fighters/Tanks? 

There has been some hints of that in the previous Itemization Passes, with Catalyst versus Lost Chapter, or with the reworked Hextech Revolver, but it didn't go as far as it should have, and it's still not satisfying. Overall, the AP Itemization still fells like a jumble of various historical items thrown together without a proper structure to it, and THAT is, in my eyes, the most damning problem, beyond any specific issue like lack of MPen or Morello crowding out other items.

Definite changes to {{item:3089}}. This item has fallen so much since S3/S4/S5. It has such an awkward build path that makes it you either need to rush it kinda early so you can buy all the 3 components but because it is so expensive, you delay reaching the necessary power spike OR you buy it near the end of the game, and there are no more item slots to get all 3 components, hence the combine cost of {{item:3089}} becomes awful.

Lost Chapter definitely needs to build into another item. The problem of Morellonomicon being a near-required rush is more a problem of the nature of spellcasting champs (you can't just rush AP like a physical champ can rush AD, you need to get something to ease mana costs as well) than a problem of the item itself.

Some items certainly need to be change and more potions must be added to make ap itemization satisfying. 

* We need more viable mana options. Morellonomicon is built 90% of the time or more, with both a good build path and since it's cost efficient. Make at least one more item building from Lost chapter. Tear is also rather weak and only bought on a few champions. Rod of ages is okay, but the build path is kinda bad.

* We need more pen items. There are no options to choose from, on most mages you want all 3 items giving magic pen. Even assassins sometimes get Liandrys when they want neither the hp or burn.

* Rabadons needs a smoother build path. Make it build out of a new mini-rabadons with 15-20% increased ap.

* Some items are basically useless atm. Rylais is way too weak and needs a change badly, especially with the new slowing keystone.

* We may need some assassin-based items. Fizz for example has insane scalings, near 100% or above on all abilitiess, due to low ap build path. If you add something meant for assassins they will be easier to balance and you can reduce scalings to prevent extreme snowballing while still making them somewhat useful when behind.

Personally? I'd recommend you guys give this as much time and attention as you did the changes you made for flat armor pen to lethality. While still not a perfect system with some areas of shortfall or abuse, lethality is an absolute improvement over the prior system of flat armor pen.

Don't rush this for the sake of getting it out quickly. Take your time, do some thorough brainstorming, and make sure you guys can be overall confident in what you push out. If you guys rush just to appease the masses, they'll simply get more infuriated.

My concern here is this: "Create contextual choices amongst items (especially amongst first items), we want items to be the correct purchase in some circumstances, and not in others."

To me this reads as "morellonomicon is too generalist and so we'll split it into two much less satisfying items"

On one hand I am RIGHT there with you, on the other hand I don't want two objectively weaker items taking their place, especially in this environment where mages are perceived as weak, especially compared to the current state of marksmen (Which is I think a mixture of both shielding being too readily available and some counterplay issues with supports and most specifically Twitch). Are you guys looking at this of the angle of remove morellonomicon and replace it with more choices or are you coming at this from a "what can we put out that could potentially compete with a morellonomicon?"

Also, have you guys considered instead of dumping mana on the first items a mage buy, spreading the mana out on many mage items?

I mean, that's exactly what happened to Brutalizer. It wasn't a finished item, true, but it was split into two items that cost the same as the original one.

And that was absolutely necessary, because Brutalizer was a dumb item, just like Morello's is a dumb item.

Riot shouldn't not make changes just because 'mages are perceived as weak', when they are very clearly still viable.

I definitely get what you mean, but perception is very important and things need to be made clear.

Let's not forget that time Vlad got "nerfed" but the nerf didn't go through and his playrate dropped dramatically.

All I'm saying is the use case of whatever new items come out of this need to be made very clear or there could be some blowback, and that's not good for anyone.
There will be blowback no matter what changes they make. League's playerbase is really good at complaining.

Please make some AP assassin items. A couple AP assassins have no use for items like Morello and have 0 way to hit 40% cdr without the item. Also itemization is forcing most AP assassins into either a Gunblade/Protobelt first buy 99% of the time. Need some dedicated AP assassin items similar to the lethality items for AD's. Also please buff seekers to finally be on par with hexdrinker thanks.
125 AP is tooooo much
It's the exact gold equivalent of 80 AD. So your problem is the 80 AD, not the 125 AP. I'm not just pulling random numbers from thin air.

An Orianna with a 125 ap item doesn't have the same impact as a Tryndamere with 80 ad item.
You need to take the champions and how they are used in the game, to modify the itemization. There is no transitivity between the ad/ap items.
its not about the gold value, it's about how there are no other 125 AP items for a reason

Correct. The reason is because the 80 AD items are stronger single buys than any AP item that currently exists. 

It's not because of damage patterns. It's not because of ratios. It's not because of DCap or auto attacks. It's because items that powerful exist for ADs and do not exist for APs. That's the end result of two consecutive seasons of net AD buffs and net AP nerfs. 

AP items have often been stronger single items because they scale additively with one another, whereas AD items scaled multiplicatively with attack speed and crit. Since season 6 that really hasn't been the case. By the end of season 7 AD items are, on the whole, stronger single items *and* scale multiplicatively.

Do you think it's just a coincidence that the ADC burst-per-second meta is a thing? Or that AD champs have dominated the solo queue ban list the entire season?
I feel a little stupid because you are utterly correct

I would say adding new upgrades to Lost Chapter may help a bit in diversity. The item itself does a lot to help early mana issue, and I'd say that "Mage group A has item X, group B has Y, etc." is at least a bit than "All mages build X".

Also, I'd prefer to see Morellonomicon keep Grievous Wounds, but just be less of a general pick. On one hand, I'd want to keep the meme of Morello's healer vendetta alive, but on the other, having GW tacked onto an item that everyone in a certain class will buy just makes things needlessly difficult for champs that rely on healing.

And finally, a bit more flat Magic Pen options would be nice. With MPen runes being removed, all we'll have are Sorc Shoes (Which can be overlooked for other boots, depending on the situation) and Haunting Guise/Liandries (Who's statline/effects are more suited to a sustained damage mage, rather than the assassins that'd want to pop squishy targets),

I think that AP shouldn't because there is a big difference you're missing here. AD's buying Pen items are assassins (unless you''re Luc or MF which I still think is kinda dumb), and they have to overcome the range difference between them and their targets a lot of the time. 

With AP, most of them are ranged, and that's a pretty big benefit. They shouldn't also have Assassin level Pen, when they don't need to risk as much as they do to get into Kill range of a target. Can you imagine Xerath having Assassin level's of Pen, with his range? It'd be stupid. 

You can not use "While AD has it, should AP should too" argument, because the two classes are significantly different. Assassins need pen to get around Armor to do their damage, that's how they've been redesigned to work during the assassin update. Throwing power behind items instead of levels helps them curve into late game without being impossible early game. 

Mages just need to throw huge numbers at people to kill them, and their bases and ratios prove that. Giving every mage to Assassin level Pen ignores the collateral abuse that some mages might take. Unless you can find a way to give AP assassins their own unabusable items, it's just not going to work.
